awd_titl_txt: Simulations of Competing Phases and Quantum Criticality in Strongly Correlated Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research funds this award that supports research and education on the development of new formalisms, algorithms and codes, and on their use in the study of complex behavior of constituent electrons in materials.

One of the most fascinating areas of materials science is the study of how electrons organize in materials, giving rise to different quantum phases, such as metals, insulators, semiconductors or superconductors, which are characterized by different and technologically important properties. Quantum criticality occurs when multiple such phases coexist and compete in a material. At the boundaries between these phases, it is possible that no well-established phase exists; as a result, completely new states of matter may emerge. These new phases and their competition is not only fascinating from a fundamental standpoint, but may also hold the promise of new applications and functionalities since at a tenuous balance between phases, the application of an electric or magnetic field, or pressure, or changes in the chemical composition of the material may dramatically change its properties. New functionalities may then emerge as the system "switches" between the different states. The project entails developing relevant methodology, and will use supercomputers to study these quantum critical states of matter, the competition between different phases, and their response to different external fields.

The research will be carried out in collaboration with researchers in India, furthering an established international collaboration involving several present and former students. The project will also involve a number of outreach efforts developed to increase student interest and achievement in the sciences, and to encourage students to consider STEM careers. The researchers funded by the award will participate in a Beowulf Bootcamp each summer where high-school students will construct and use a small supercomputer.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research funds this award that supports research and education on complex behaviors in correlated electronic materials, including competing phases in cuprate superconductors, heavy-Fermion systems, and disordered interacting electronic systems and superconductors. Special emphasis will be placed on identifying and studying new quantum critical points and competing phases, and the Anderson disorder-driven quantum phase transition and its competition with interactions.

The goal of this project is to continue the development of new formalisms, algorithms and codes, and to use them in the study complex behavior in correlated electronic materials. The research team will focus on simulations of quantum criticality and disordered interacting models near localization. Quantum criticality is of great fundamental interest, since the associated transitions are driven by quantum rather than thermal fluctuations. The PI and his group will develop a better understanding of the competing phases in correlated and strongly disordered systems that could lead to new functionalities, including the Anderson metal-insulator transition, and other quantum phase transitions. A more complete understanding of quantum criticality may in turn lead to a better understanding of high-temperature superconductors and other technologically important materials.

The project will employ an array of theoretical/computational tools including multiscale approaches, quantum Monte Carlo, and fast approximate cluster solvers, and novel methods to treat disordered interacting systems near an Anderson localization transition including the recently developed typical-medium dynamical cluster approximation used to study the Anderson localization quantum phase transition.

The research will be carried out in collaboration with researchers in India, furthering an established international collaboration involving several present and former students. The project will also involve a number of outreach efforts developed to increase student interest and achievement in the sciences, and to encourage students to consider STEM careers. The researchers funded by the award will participate in a Beowulf Bootcamp each summer where high-school students will construct and use a small supercomputer.

por.por_cntn:
There are many vastly different states of matter besides simple solid, gas, and liquid. The computers and cellphones we use everyday are powered by chips which are made out of semiconductors. Other more exotic states of matter are superconductors that play an important part in the medical imaging of  magnetic resonance imaging and numerical magnetic resonance. A major goal of condensed matter physics is to understand the formation of many different phases of matter from the atoms which the materials are composed of. Ultimately we would like to have a recipe to engineer the properties of materials out of atoms. 

 

While the fundamental constituents of materials are all atoms, it is clear that the property of materials cannot be simply understood in terms of atoms. The collective behaviors cannot be simply understood from an individual behavior. Condensed matter physics is a discipline which studies such collective behaviors due to the competitions and cooperations of electrons and nuclei from atoms. In particular for computational condensed matter physics, we would like to utilize the state-of-the-art supercomputers and numerical algorithms to understand the properties of materials. 

 

It is rather unrealistic to study directly each individual atom even with the best supercomputer. An approximation often involved in simplifying the calculations is to reduce the spatial resolution of the calculations. A rather successful theory is the mean field approximation, for which the spatial resolution is reduced to the minimum possible. The generalization of mean field approximation to quantum mechanical systems, such as systems composed of electrons is the dynamical mean field theory (DMFT). 

 

The DMFT has been studied extensively over the past three decades, it is a tremendously successful theory as it drastically reduces the cost of computation. However, the lack of spatial resolution renders it impossible to address some of the most important problems in condensed matter physics. For example, the superconductivity in the cuprate is angular dependent and thus spatial resolution is required to capture it. The proposal of the dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) partially relieved the deficit of theDMFT. 

 

The cuprates superconductor remains a central topic in condensed matter physics; there is no consensus on the mechanism of the high temperature superconductivity more than three decades since it was discovered. However, it is widely believed that the key to understanding superconductivity is to understand the unusual metallic behavior for temperature above the critical temperature, that is the regime above the superconducting dome in the phase diagram. A prominent solution for explaining the unusual metallic behaviors is the marginal fermi liquid theory. 

 

All metals are in a way described by the fermi liquid theory, in short even with all the messy interaction among electrons, "active" electrons can still be described in terms of "free" electrons or quasi-particles. The major change is that the mass of the electrons becomes heavier than that in the truly free system and also the so-called "life-time" of the particles becomes finite.

 

The marginal fermi liquid assumes that the interacting electrons cannot be described by a simple quasi-particle picture and their life-time is short enough that cannot be neglected. An underlying assumption of the marginal fermi liquid theory is that the system possesses a quantum critical point at zero temperature.

 

One of the major goals of the present project is to use existing computational algorithms and to invent new approaches to capture the quantum critical point. We are particularly interested in the three dimensional systems. Using the DCA we obtained evidence of marginal fermi liquid. We also adapted the recent advances in the techniques of data science, machine learning, and quantum computing algorithms to design new approaches for capturing phase transitions and quantum critical points. 

 

Besides the scientific research, the project sponsored the training of three graduate students and two postdocs. Our computational projects provided plenty of opportunity in the training of programming skills and data science techniques. The students and postdocs are highly marketable in both academic and industry. A graduate student supported by the project is currently working in the L3-Harris to design the programming of autonomous amphibious vehicles. A postdoc supported by the project is currently working in Lawrence Berkeley National Lab for using the machine learning natural language processing techniques to study materials properties based on data mining. 

 

We also sponsored boot camps for high school students to learn and even build computer clusters, the basic building block of supercomputers, out of Raspberry Pi cards. Every summer, we mentored undergraduate students for conducting research in condensed matter physics and computational physics. One of the summer students completed a paper on detecting quantum critical points and published it in a journal. Another summer student has won the best poster prize at PhysCon 2022 in the category of Complex Systems/Stat Mech/Non Linearity.
